name.text: 20.3.2.1 The Laplace transform of a derivative

questiontext.text:
The Laplace transform of a derivative

Here we consider not a causal function \(f(t)\) directly but its derivatives \(\displaystyle{df\over {dt}}\), \(\displaystyle{d^2f\over {dt^2}}\), (which are also causal.) The Laplace transform of derivatives will be invaluable when we apply the Laplace transform to the solution of constant coefficient ordinary differential equations.

If \({\cal L}\{f(t)\}\) is \(F(s)\) then we shall seek an expression for \(\displaystyle{\cal L}\{{df\over {dt}}\}\) in terms of the function \(F(s)\).

Now, by the definition of the Laplace transform \[ {\cal L}\biggl\{{df\over {dt}}\biggr\}=\int_0^{\infty}\text{e}^{-st}{df\over {dt}}\,dt\] This integral can be simplified using integration by parts:

\[\begin{eqnarray*} \int_0^{\infty}\text{e}^{-st}{df\over {dt}}\,dt&=&\biggl[\text{e}^{-st}f(t)\biggr]_0^{\infty}-\int_0^{\infty}(-s)\text{e}^{-st}f(t)\,dt\\ &=&-f(0)+s\int_0^{\infty}\text{e}^{-st}f(t)\,dt \end{eqnarray*}\] (As usual, we assume that contributions arising from the upper limit, \(t=\infty\), are zero.) The integral on the right-hand side is precisely the Laplace transform of \(f(t)\) which we naturally replace by \(F(s)\). Thus \[ {\cal L}\biggl\{{df\over {dt}}\biggr\}=-f(0)+sF(s)\]

As an example, we know that if \(f(t)=\sin t\ u(t)\) then \[{\cal L}\{f(t)\}={1\over {s^2+1}}= F(s)\] and so, according to the result just obtained,

\[\begin{eqnarray*} {\cal L}\biggl\{ \frac{df}{dt} \biggr\}={\cal L}\{\cos t\ u(t)\}&=&-f(0)+sF(s)\\ &=&0+s\biggl({1\over {s^2+1}}\biggr)\\ &=&{s\over {s^2+1}} \end{eqnarray*}\] a result we know to be true.

We can find the Laplace transform of the second derivative in a similar way to find:

\[\displaystyle{\cal L}\biggl\{{d^2f\over {dt^2}}\biggr\}=-f'(0)-sf(0)+s^2F(s)\] (The reader might wish to derive this result.) Here \(f'(0)\) is the derivative of \(f(t)\) evaluated at \(t=0\).

Key Point

Laplace Transforms of Derivatives

If \({\cal L}\{f(t)\}=F(s)\) then\[\begin{eqnarray*}{\cal L}\biggl\{{df\over {dt}}\biggr\}&=&-f(0)+sF(s)\\ {\cal L}\biggl\{{d^2f\over {dt^2}}\biggr\}&=&-f'(0)-sf(0)+s^2F(s)\end{eqnarray*}\]
